responses.content: Today, we're reporting $143.1 billion in revenue, up 11% year-over-year; $11.2 billion in operating income, up 343% year-over-year or $8.7 billion.
$20.2 billion in trailing 12-month free cash flow adjusted for equipment finance leases, up $41.7 billion versus the comparable period last year.
We continue to be encouraged by the progress we're making in lowering our cost to serve, improving our customer experiences, and investing for future growth.
Our redesign of the fulfillment network from a national to an 8-region model has exceeded expectations, resulting in shorter travel distances, lower costs, and faster delivery speeds.
We are on pace to deliver the fastest delivery speeds for Prime customers in our 29-year history, significantly enhancing customer satisfaction and purchase frequency.

AWS revenue grew 12% year-over-year in Q3, reaching an annualized run rate of $92 billion. Our investments in generative AI and large language models continue to position AWS as a leader in this space.
Advertising revenue grew 25% year-over-year, driven by sponsored products and our focus on machine learning to improve ad relevancy and measurement capabilities.
We have streamlined our investments to focus on high-impact areas, including streaming entertainment, low Earth orbit satellites with Project Kuiper, and healthcare initiatives.
Our grocery business, including Whole Foods and Amazon Fresh, continues to expand with new formats and strategies to optimize our physical store footprint and enhance offerings.
Amazon Business has reached a $35 billion annual gross sales run rate, with plans to grow it to a $100 billion-plus business by adding new features and services tailored to enterprise needs.
We anticipate significant AI-driven monetization in AWS, particularly with generative AI and large language models, expecting this impact to grow in the future.
Prime Video remains a key part of the Prime value proposition, with investments in exclusive content and the introduction of limited advertisements to enhance profitability.
Our international stores are improving in customer experience and profitability. Initiatives like Buy with Prime and Supply Chain by Amazon are receiving positive responses from sellers.
Amazon Pharmacy has evolved significantly, offering affordable medication options and partnering with Blue Shield of California to enhance pharmacy care.
Project Kuiper made progress with the successful launch of 2 prototype satellites, advancing our mission to provide fast, affordable broadband to underserved communities.
We are gearing up for the annual AWS re:Invent conference and the 29th holiday shopping season, with Prime Big Deal Days marking a successful start to the holiday season.
Worldwide revenue was $143.1 billion, representing an 11% year-over-year increase and approximately $100 million above the top end of our guidance range.
Operating income reached $11.2 billion for the quarter, an increase of $8.7 billion year-over-year, significantly exceeding our guidance.
North America revenue was $87.9 billion, and international revenue was $32.1 billion, both up 11% year-over-year excluding foreign exchange.
We held our biggest Prime Day event ever, with Prime members purchasing over 375 million items worldwide and saving more than $2.5 billion.
Customers remain cautious about pricing, trading down where possible, and seeking deals, particularly in everyday essentials and personal care categories.
We set another record for delivery speed, delivering the fastest speeds ever in the United States for the year-to-date period through Q3.
Third-party sellers grew by 18% year-over-year, driven by selection expansion and increased adoption of our optional services like Fulfillment by Amazon.
Advertising revenue grew 25% year-over-year, driven by sponsored products and enhanced machine learning algorithms improving ad relevancy and performance.
North America operating margins improved to 4.9%, up 100 basis points quarter-over-quarter. International segment operating loss improved to $95 million.

Free cash flow adjusted for finance leases was $20.2 billion for the trailing 12-month period, up $41.7 billion year-over-year. Capital investments were $50 billion for the trailing 12-month period, down from $60 billion the prior year.
For the full year 2023, we expect capital investments to be approximately $50 billion, with fulfillment and transportation CapEx down year-over-year.

questions: As you look forward in the fourth quarter, are you seeing less cost optimization in AWS compared to Q3, or do you think it will be similar?
You noticed a big margin improvement in AWS back to where you were 7 quarters ago. Could you talk about the drivers and sustainability of those margins?
How is the regional fulfillment network exceeding your expectations?
How does the regional network support your confidence in moving North America beyond mid-single-digit margin levels?
Regarding generative AI, how should we think about the timing for tangible monetization in AWS?
Could you discuss the early generative AI products where you're seeing the most demand and interest, and any upcoming innovations?
With the regionalization of warehouses, where are you on robotics, and how might that impact profitability?
How might the new IT budget cycle in 2024 shift focus from optimization to AI initiatives?
In your advertising business approaching a $50 billion run rate, what initiatives are you most excited about to continue scaling both on and off Amazon?
Were the new AWS deals in the September quarter different in terms of industries, verticals, or geographies?
Is the international segment now sustainably profitable, offsetting any seasonally challenged quarters?
